questions.question: He did not allow me ……………………….
questions.description: We use a to-infinitive after allow.

questions.question: The injured woman ………………………….. to hospital.
questions.description: We need a passive verb form here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: We ……………………………… anything from them yet.
questions.description: The present perfect is more common with the time expressions already and yet.

questions.question: The chief guest ………………………………… arrived.
questions.description: The present perfect is more common with the time expressions already and yet.

questions.question: ‘Let me ………………………….,’ the boy cried.
questions.description: We use an infinitive without to after let.

questions.question: The birds …………………………….. when I woke up this morning.
questions.description: We use the past continuous to talk about an action or situation that was going on a particular point of time in the past.

questions.question: I heard them ……………………………..
questions.description: We use a gerund or an infinitive without to after the verbs see and hear.

questions.question: Yesterday I …………………………….. an English movie.
questions.description: We use the simple past to talk about finished past events.

questions.question: The constable asked me what …………………………….. doing there.
questions.description: The subject goes before the verb in an indirect question.

questions.question: I ……………………………. like to get up early in the morning.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about our likes and dislikes.

questions.question: Ever since I ………………………….. my native place I ………………………………. here.
questions.description: We use the simple past for finished actions or situations in the past. We use the present perfect continuous to talk about an action or situation that started in the past and has continued up to the present.
